quotes.topic_title: Process reduces variance, can dampen top performers
quotes.text: Process, by definition, is variance reducing.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for evaluating any new process: it primarily reduces variability, not necessarily increases excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Process reduces variance, can dampen top performers
quotes.text: You're introducing it, because you worry that the variance in your org is too high.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Clarifies the real trigger for adding process—fear of inconsistency—so leaders can be explicit about the tradeoff they’re making.

quotes.topic_title: Process reduces variance, can dampen top performers
quotes.text: And the cost of that is obviously, while you are reducing the standard and bringing folks up to the average, you're also bringing other folks down to the average.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive downside of standardization: it can compress performance by lowering the ceiling as it raises the floor.

quotes.topic_title: Process reduces variance, can dampen top performers
quotes.text: And oftentimes, the folks you're bringing down are your highest performers, your most creative thinkers.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A warning for practitioners designing process: the people most harmed may be the ones driving outsized innovation and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Process reduces variance, can dampen top performers
quotes.text: The folks who, I think actually don't really need process to do their best work.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Suggests a practical lens for tailoring process—apply it where it raises the floor, but avoid constraining those who already self-manage effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She was actually one of their very first PMs, where she helped build some of their foundational products like Stripe Checkout, Stripe Connect, Stripe Radar, and Stripe Chargeback Protection.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights concrete examples of foundational products Eeke worked on, establishing credibility and signaling the kinds of systems-level product lessons to expect.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We covered Stripe's internal culture and what makes it so unique and innovative.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to culture as a primary lever for innovation, teeing up learnings practitioners can apply beyond tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: How to foster and protect innovation at your own company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames innovation as something that must be actively protected, not just encouraged—an actionable stance for leaders designing org systems.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What is the right amount of process by stage of company?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a stage-dependent process model, implying teams should calibrate process rather than default to “more” or “less.”

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: How to build a talent portfolio.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests a portfolio approach to talent (mixing profiles/skills), a useful mental model for hiring and team design.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a great shared space to work closely with your colleagues, to capture ideas, get feedback, and iterate quickly and easily on anything you're working on.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical collaboration loop (capture → feedback → iterate) teams can apply to speed up execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For example, in Miro, you can build out your product strategy by brainstorming with sticky notes, comments, live reactions, a voting tool. Even an estimation app, to scope out your team sprints.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, step-by-step set of tools for turning strategy brainstorming into prioritized and scoped sprint work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And, with one of Miro's readymade templates, you can go from discovery and research, to your product roadmap, to customer journey flows, to final mocks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers an end-to-end workflow model for moving from research to execution artifacts using templates.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Notion to coordinate this very podcast, including my content calendar, my sponsors, and prepping guests for the launch of each episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a specific real-world use case showing how to centralize planning and operations in a single workspace.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And not only does it allow you to be more efficient in your work life, but you can easily transition to using it in your personal life, which is another feature that truly sets Notion apart.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests a transferable system: reuse the same organizational tool across work and personal projects for consistency and leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe early days: roles, Connect, Radar
quotes.text: And to this day, when people ask me, "Hey, what's your advice for going into product management?" I'm like, "Well, you should go get a sales job. I think it's pretty valuable."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice: sales work can be a high-leverage way to build core PM skills through constant customer exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe early days: roles, Connect, Radar
quotes.text: But it also really wasn't your typical sales job, in that most of Stripes volume was inbound. So I was really just spending all of my day talking to customers, helping them figure out how Stripe might work for their particular business flows, and payment models.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Shows a practical model for customer-driven product discovery: use customer conversations to map real workflows and constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe early days: roles, Connect, Radar
quotes.text: And then on top of that, all these platforms and marketplaces started having all these pretty complex regulatory and compliance requirements that were pretty different, country to country.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights a key product/infra lesson for marketplaces: complexity often comes from cross-border compliance, not just payments flow mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe early days: roles, Connect, Radar
quotes.text: But if a merchant processes a payment from a customer and that customer used a stolen credit card, the merchant is ultimately on the hook for those funds.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete, surprising data point about incentives in payments that explains why fraud tooling is existential for many merchants.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe early days: roles, Connect, Radar
quotes.text: But it was also really cool from a product perspective, because of all the kind of complicated product questions around how humans should interact with AI and models. And I imagine a lot of the folks in the latest movement in AI are thinking a lot about that too. It's like, "How do you explain a model to humans? How do you let them interact with it?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Frames an enduring AI product design problem—explainability and user control—as central to building trust and usability.

quotes.topic_title: Why Stripe delayed PM hiring
quotes.text: And I think actually both in the Stripe case and the Retool case, the thing that both of these companies have in common is, you're building for developers. The people who are building the product are the customers in a lot of ways.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights a key condition where PMs may be less necessary early: when builders and users are essentially the same group.

quotes.topic_title: Why Stripe delayed PM hiring
quotes.text: So, they get it. There's really no reason why you should have, in some ways, a middle man trying to figure out, "Hey, who's the customer, and what is it that they need?" And what are their pain points?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A contrarian argument for delaying PM hiring when engineers have direct customer empathy and feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Why Stripe delayed PM hiring
quotes.text: And I think the moment at which it became clear, "We really do need PMs at Stripe." And I think we felt the same way at Retool is, your customer base starts expanding. You start having different kinds of customers. You need to understand the whole market, all of the ICPs that you're going after.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Defines a practical trigger for adding PMs: customer diversification and the need to manage multiple ICPs and market understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Why Stripe delayed PM hiring
quotes.text: And the organization gets more complex. I think Stripe... Gosh, in particular, it's just an extremely matrixed organization in business. Because every time you launch a product, you're having to think about, "Well, how do we do this in other countries? There's different financial infrastructure. How do we think about the legal side, the compliance side, et cetera?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of complexity (globalization, legal/compliance) that increases coordination needs and makes PM leverage higher.

quotes.topic_title: Why Stripe delayed PM hiring
quotes.text: And I think PMs can really kind of bring that whole story together and make the whole machine move.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of PM value in complex orgs: integrating cross-functional constraints into a coherent narrative and execution engine.

quotes.topic_title: What PM work really entails
quotes.text: I say this often actually, to folks who are thinking about going into product management. "That's awesome. Just be really, really sure about what you're signing up for."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A clear-eyed reminder to validate you actually want the day-to-day reality of PM work before pursuing the role.

quotes.topic_title: What PM work really entails
quotes.text: But just so you know, being a manager is like, "Hey, you're doing performance reviews a lot. And you're in one-on-ones a lot." You have to really love that kind of work.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for management: the job is largely recurring people-process work, so motivation must match the actual tasks.

quotes.topic_title: What PM work really entails
quotes.text: And I think in the product management case, it's also like, you're constantly working across a lot of different teams. You're trying to influence a lot of people who don't report into you directly, to do a bunch of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Defines PM as influence-without-authority and cross-team coordination—useful for setting expectations and building the right skills.

quotes.topic_title: What PM work really entails
quotes.text: And I imagine people get into product thinking they're going to have all this control, power, influence. And then they're like, "Oh my God, this job is so freaking crazy. What did I sign up for?"
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Challenges the common misconception that PM equals control, highlighting the gap between perceived authority and real complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe culture: rigorous thinking and writing
quotes.text: And actually, when we put out the guide, our metric of success was that, more of the right people would apply to Stripe and fewer of the wrong people.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Defines a practical, measurable way to evaluate culture documentation: improve applicant self-selection.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe culture: rigorous thinking and writing
quotes.text: There was this humongous respect and enthusiasm for thinking. It was such a part of the culture. One of the values was, think rigorously. Every meeting was very much like, "Hey, how do we think about this thing from first principle?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable cultural mechanism—explicit first-principles reasoning in meetings—to drive better decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe culture: rigorous thinking and writing
quotes.text: And I very strongly believe this. I don't think you can be a good writer, unless you're a clear thinker.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A crisp rationale for using writing as a forcing function for clarity and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe culture: rigorous thinking and writing
quotes.text: It's like, "If you make this decision, is it one door, or is it two doors? Can you come back from this decision?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A simple mental model for deciding when to move fast versus slow based on reversibility.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe culture: rigorous thinking and writing
quotes.text: So I think a lot of people, for example, think pricing is a trapdoor decision. But actually, it's really easy to grandfather your existing users into some existing pricing model and change pricing for future users.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Counterintuitive example showing pricing is often reversible, enabling faster iteration than teams assume.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing first principles and operating principles
quotes.text: And actually, to this day, when I'm preparing a memo, or a board deck, or something. I imagine in my head, I'm like, "What if I had to present this to Patrick?" And my ideas just get so much better, because I can sort of think about the questions they would ask.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A practical technique for raising the rigor of your thinking by mentally simulating a high-bar reviewer.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing first principles and operating principles
quotes.text: Once you start writing things down, you realize, "Hey, that actually doesn't make a lot of sense."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights writing as an operational mechanism that exposes weak logic and forces first-principles clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing first principles and operating principles
quotes.text: And I think this is actually how Stripe got its start. I think when Stripe started, if you wanted to set up a merchant account, it could take weeks. And everyone just assumed that's what it took. And of course John and Patrick were like, "Well, it doesn't actually make that much sense why it should take that long."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete example of questioning industry defaults to find leverage for innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing first principles and operating principles
quotes.text: And Stripe would call them operating principles, actually. Which, I think is actually better. Because values, you can't really tell people what to value. Everyone has their own value set. But you can tell people like, "Hey, here's how we operate."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A reframing that makes culture more actionable by focusing on behaviors (“how we operate”) rather than abstract values.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing first principles and operating principles
quotes.text: Yeah. It was just this idea that, "In the long term, we expect the curve to go up. We very much believe in the upward trajectory of just about everything. But on the day-to-day decisions, on the minutiae, we're quite critical. How do we make sure this thing works?" And we'd think about all the ways in which it doesn't work.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for balancing optimism about the mission with rigorous skepticism in execution.

quotes.topic_title: How to foster innovation and big thinking
quotes.text: I actually think about the extremes of that question. So not, "Why are some teams innovative?" But, "Why isn't every team innovative?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A reframing that pushes leaders to look for systemic blockers to innovation rather than treating innovation as a rare trait.

quotes.topic_title: How to foster innovation and big thinking
quotes.text: I think leaders want the upside of innovation, but they're not really willing to deal with the cost of innovation. Which is like, "Look, if you're going to swing big, you will invariably stumble sometimes."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that big bets require accepting failure as an inherent cost, not an exception.

quotes.topic_title: How to foster innovation and big thinking
quotes.text: You have to figure out how to give folks more at BATS.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: increase iteration frequency to lower stakes and make bold experimentation safer.

quotes.topic_title: How to foster innovation and big thinking
quotes.text: So I call this... You have to give teams permission to think. So create these moments in your company culture, in your overall business processes, where you're asking people, you're literally saying, "Hey, this is part of your job to think bigger."
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Actionable advice to operationalize “big thinking” by explicitly making it a required part of the work, not an extracurricular.

quotes.topic_title: How to foster innovation and big thinking
quotes.text: So at Retool, we have these team charters and we do team planning. And at the bottom of every team charter we have a section called, Think Bigger. "With 20% more time, what would you do that isn't on this list already?"
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete process prompt teams can copy to systematically surface non-incremental opportunities during planning.

quotes.topic_title: Making failure safe and funding exploration time
quotes.text: So every year that we send out the doc, we look at the doc from the past year, and we're like, "Okay, did we do anything on this list?" And consistently, we do anywhere between three to eight things on the list.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete accountability loop plus a measurable outcome that shows “crazy ideas” lists can reliably produce shipped work.

quotes.topic_title: Making failure safe and funding exploration time
quotes.text: To me, it's always in the follow-ups. So have people talk about the failure in these sort of public forums, where usually you talk about the successes.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A practical mechanism for making failure safe: normalize it by giving failures the same public airtime as wins.

quotes.topic_title: Making failure safe and funding exploration time
quotes.text: On the top-down, sometimes you just have to be willing to fund someone with something. Like, they come to you with an idea and you're like, "Look, yeah, take an engineer and go do it." And you just have to give folks that sort of organizational buy-in.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A leadership playbook for creating exploration capacity: explicitly allocate people/time rather than waiting for perfect certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Making failure safe and funding exploration time
quotes.text: And then, I think more than anything, in people's planning processes, I really like asking folks the 20% more time question. Or the other question was, "Look, if you doubled the team today, what would you do?" That shows up in our planning processes as well.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A simple planning prompt that forces teams to escape incremental thinking and surface higher-leverage bets.

quotes.topic_title: Making failure safe and funding exploration time
quotes.text: But I actually think the trick is less structure, in those cases. Because you don't really want to sort of pigeonhole... Or make it even that intimidating for folks. If someone just wants to write down a few bullets, that's great.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A counterintuitive guideline for big-idea generation: reduce process/format constraints to lower intimidation and increase participation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams should anticipate: experimentation is mandatory, but tooling may not fit modern stacks out of the box.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to a waste of time building internal tools, or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out a common operational failure mode and tradeoff practitioners can avoid by choosing fit-for-purpose experimentation infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform, was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a concrete methodology for analysis: segment experiment results across key dimensions to uncover meaningful differences.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Delivering results quickly, avoiding annoying prolonged analytics cycles, and helping you easily get to the root cause of any issue you discover.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes speed-to-insight and root-cause analysis as core requirements for effective experimentation programs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics and instead, use their North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Recommends a measurement model shift from shallow engagement metrics to business-meaningful North Star outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Launching three Retool products in one year
quotes.text: we really had one or two people working on each of these products for the first six months. So it was one engineer and one designer, or one engineer and one PM. And they really didn't get funding until it was clear that there was something there.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete staffing-and-funding approach: start with tiny teams and scale only after early validation.

quotes.topic_title: Launching three Retool products in one year
quotes.text: we really treated them like startups. We're like, Retool's the VC, and Retool funds with resources and Retool's existing customer base.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A memorable internal-venture model for running new product bets inside an existing company.

quotes.topic_title: Launching three Retool products in one year
quotes.text: But then, the teams really had to prove that ROI. Either in engagement, or eventually revenue, in order to be able to move forward.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A clear gating mechanism for investment decisions that prevents scaling initiatives without measurable traction.

quotes.topic_title: Launching three Retool products in one year
quotes.text: we were really deliberate about keeping these teams separate from the rest of the org, especially early on.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org-design choice to preserve speed and independent thinking during early-stage product development.

quotes.topic_title: Launching three Retool products in one year
quotes.text: we eventually decided that we were going to run it as a separate team, because we wanted the team to be able to move really, really quickly. And we didn't want it to get bogged down in, what are just the realities of running a product that has product market fit, like bugs, yada, yada, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A practical rationale for isolating new bets from core-product operational drag to maintain momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Right amount of process by company stage
quotes.text: Process, by definition, is variance reducing. You're introducing it, because you worry that the variance in your org is too high. You want people to sort of meet a certain standard.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for why process exists: it’s a tool to reduce organizational variance and enforce a baseline standard.

quotes.topic_title: Right amount of process by company stage
quotes.text: And the cost of that is obviously, while you are reducing the standard and bringing folks up to the average, you're also bringing other folks down to the average.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Highlights the core tradeoff of process: raising the floor can simultaneously lower the ceiling.

quotes.topic_title: Right amount of process by company stage
quotes.text: And oftentimes, the folks you're bringing down are your highest performers, your most creative thinkers. The folks who, I think actually don't really need process to do their best work.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that process can disproportionately constrain the people who drive outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: Right amount of process by company stage
quotes.text: Because when we were at Stripe and we were trying to figure out our planning process, we actually talked to Amazon, and Atlassian, and Apple, and all these companies that we really, really respect and look up to.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: A concrete example of benchmarking process against admired companies—useful, but with pitfalls at different stages.

quotes.topic_title: Right amount of process by company stage
quotes.text: And I remember taking down notes from these companies and being like, "Yeah, this is awesome, but there's no way that this will work for Stripe." Stripe was so much smaller than any of these companies.
quotes.speaker: Eeke de Milliano
quotes.context: Emphasizes stage-appropriateness: copying “big company” process can fail when your org is much smaller.
